ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Cell Bio 900 is the mandatory class that the department makes you take to fulfill grant requirements like ethics training. If it were not required, I would not recommend the course, as generally it provides no benefit.
Unfortunately everyone HAS to take this class. I think it could be made a lot more interesting, but I understand that certain topics must be covered to fulfill a requirement.
No; I really don't think this course should be required beyond rotation& faculty talks; I don't think it was a good use of time. But they won't have a choice!
not that helpful. but mildly interesting.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: Generally this course did not deepen my knowledge of my profession, nor contribute to my research beyond the opportunity to present my rotation research.
It was great that we were able to give presentations. It was nice to hear about everyone else's work and to be able to hone my own presentation skills.

It was helpful to get to know the professors during faculty talks (the 'happy hour' afterwords was a great idea); and to practice presentation skills. Otherwise I feel that it did not contribute to my training.
did help to go over nsf proposals. most of the other classes were not that helpful though.
It was occasionally informative, but not always.
This course helped me to discover the resources that are available at Yale during my graduate studies.
